Projected total daily hospital admissions, those to the intensive care unit, and those requiring invasive mechanical ventilation for patients with COVID-19 Figure 2 . Sensitivity analysis results demonstrating a range of epidemic scenarios

We constructed a traditional SIR model based on the framework proposed by Kermack and McKendrick (1) . This approach assumes three states of patients, including those susceptible to disease ( ), those infected with the virus ( ), and those removed from developing the virus ( ), due to acquired immunity or death. Our model does not distinguish between immunity or death once populations are considered removed. The changes in the relative size of these populations are given by the following system of differential equations:

Here represents the rate of transmission of the virus and is the recovery rate (thus −1 is the duration of the infection during which transmission can occur). The total population ( ) is assumed constant such that at any given time ,

The number of infections caused by each infected individual is determined by the number of susceptible invidivuals, the rate of transmission, and the time during which an individual is infectious, given by

Although the dynamics of this SIR model may be reproduced using a closed-form analysis, we opted to use a discrete-time simulation to allow for future flexibility in modifiying population states and transitions.
